7.48pm GMT

So does Pochettino!

â€œI am worried for both sides because the pitch is not in the best condition. The most important thing is that the players finish the game in a very good level.

7.44pm GMT

From Marie Meyer: â€œI recall a Liverpool having a Champions League match somewhere in Eastern Europe years ago. Jerzy Dudek was getting ready to take a goal kick. You know how goalkeepers sort of mindlessly bounce the ball while they wait for the outfield players to sort themselves out? Dudek did that. â€œTommy Dochertyâ€™s deliberately waterlogged wings against Barcelona in the 1960s springs to mind,â€ writes Carl Jepson.

7.39pm GMT

That rings a bell. Delap era?

Good one. Keep them coming!

Decent snapshot of the job Pochettino has done at Spurs ...

Itâ€™d rival Darren Bent and the beach ball.

On to some football and hereâ€™s Ed Aarons on Maurico Pochettinoâ€™s sense of discontentment.

Whooooaaaa! Does everything in this ultra-serious Premier League of ours really have to be gleamingly splendrous all the time? I do take the indirect point that Spursâ€™ stadium situation has gone/is going very badly and that this is an unfortunate consequence of that.

7.12pm GMT

Iâ€™ll talk about some actual football in a bit but look what we did for you back in 2016! A Joy of Six: Sporting Pitch Fiascos! Will tonight make seven?

Interesting snippet from the wires, reporting that the match officials have been doing their due diligence on the surface:

Parts of the pitch are lush and green, but there are large areas of worn brown turf, especially on each touchline, while the NFL logo is still visible in the centre circle.

Referee Kevin Friend and his fellow match officials walked around the pitch at around 6pm with a ball testing to see how it rolls.

â€œWembley has come a long way from 1970 when domesticated equines tore up the pitch before the FA Cup final with the Horse of the Year Show,â€ notes Justin Kavanagh. â€œThese days its Jaguars from Jacksonville and Philadelphian Eagles ruining the footie! Thatâ€™s interesting â€“ Christian Eriksen and Kevin De Bruyne are both on the bench. Both have had their injury troubles. Is that a reaction from both managers to the pitch issue? Either way, itâ€™s potentially a shame for the spectacle.

â€œFaded American football stripes on a torn-up Wembley turf for a Premier League match?â€ observes Peter Oh. â€œOh the irony! Or should I say, the gridirony?â€

webTitle: Online gambling, cigarettes and wine hit by 'sin' taxes increase

fields.headline: Online gambling, cigarettes and wine hit by 'sin' taxes increase
fields.standfirst: But budget provides good news for beer and spirits drinkers with unexpected duty freeze
fields.trailText: But budget provides good news for beer and spirits drinkers with unexpected duty freeze
fields.body:
Vices including online gambling, smoking cigarettes and drinking wine or champagne will be hit by increased â€œsinâ€ taxes, but lovers of beer and spirits escaped with an unexpected duty freeze in Philip Hammondâ€™s budget.

The shake-up means:

  • A bottle of wine goes up by 7p, sparkling wine by 10p.

  • Average pack of 20 cigarettes to rise above Â£10.

  • Online gambling hit by Â£1bn taxes over five years.

The governmentâ€™s decision earlier this year to cut the maximum stake on fixed-odds betting terminals (FOBTs) from Â£100 to Â£2 triggered an overhaul of gambling tax, due to take effect in October.

Lost revenue from the machine gaming duty levied on FOBTs is expected to cost the exchequer Â£1.15bn over five years, according to Treasury projections.

It will make up for the shortfall by increasing the tax on online casino games from 15% to 21%, raising an estimated Â£1.25bn over the same period.

While the tweaks to gambling tax will cancel each other out fiscally, both FOBT campaigners and online gambling companies are likely to be unhappy.

Campaigners against FOBTs, who say they are highly addictive, criticised the decision to postpone FOBT curbs until October last year, as revealed by the Guardian last week.

Labourâ€™s deputy leader, Tom Watson, said: â€œBy rolling back on their promises the government are allowing greed to triumph over good as the bookies trouser an additional Â£900m in revenue.

â€œThe new secretary of state has let down not only his predecessors who campaigned for urgent change, but all the gambling charities, reformers and addicts who were relying on him not to bow to the will of the Treasury.â€

The chancellor surprised the beer and pubs industry by cancelling duty hikes on beer and spirits, which were expected to see a 3.4% rise in line with inflation, but wine duty will continue to rise.

Jackie Parker, the national chairman of real ale enthusiastsâ€™ group Camra, said the freeze would â€œno doubt go some way to keeping the British pub-going tradition affordableâ€.

The Wine and Spirit Trade Association said distillers would welcome the cancellation of a rise in spirits duty but said winemakers would be hit with an extra Â£90m bill.

â€œIt actively undermines a sector that has been hardest hit since the Brexit referendum and will be thoroughly unwelcome for the 33 million consumers of the nationâ€™s most popular alcoholic drink,â€ said the associationâ€™s chief executive, Miles Beale.

The tobacco escalator, under which tax on cigarettes goes up by inflation plus 2% each year, will continue, meaning the average cost of a packet of 20 cigarettes will rise above Â£10 for the first time.

webTitle: Englandâ€™s trickiest Test dilemma: to stick or twist with Stuart Broad

fields.headline: Englandâ€™s trickiest Test dilemma: to stick or twist with Stuart Broad
fields.standfirst: Joe Root keeps Englandâ€™s options open as they gear up for the opening Test against Sri Lanka with seamerâ€™s place one of several difficult decisions ahead
fields.trailText: Joe Root keeps Englandâ€™s options open as they gear up for the Test series in Sri Lanka with the seamerâ€™s place one of several difficult decisions ahead
fields.body:
If there is no cricket scheduled in Colombo the sun shines obediently. England were able to set to work at the Nondescripts ground in the heart of Colombo with their red balls. On Tuesday they begin the first of two two-day practice matches. These are not first-class games and they may prove to be an ugly spectacle as all the batsmen bat and all the bowlers bowl.

These matches will hardly be a contest; from Englandâ€™s perspective they are more likely to be a series of little battles between players eager to nail down a place for the first Test in Galle on 6 November.

Joe Root, bright and breezy after missing the T20 match on Saturday â€“ â€œI was rested, I thinkâ€ â€“ could hardly afford to give much away. â€œWe have to be smart because we donâ€™t know how much time we will have [because of the weather] and we all have to make the most of our opportunities.â€

Related: Cricket Australia 'arrogant' and partly to blame for ball-tampering, report finds

Root could do no more than offer steers: there was no guarantee Jonny Bairstow will be fit for the first Test, in which case Jos Buttler behind the stumps was â€œthe likely scenarioâ€, though the presence of Ben Foakes â€œgives us another way to balance the side upâ€. It remains Rootâ€™s preference to bat at four.

The simple truth is Root and Trevor Bayliss are not absolutely certain who their best team are. Hence there was much talk of the virtue of having so many options and the importance of the next four days of practice, which are likely to be painful to watch and, for several borderliners in the squad, stressful to play in.

There are tricky decisions to be made everywhere and perhaps the trickiest relates to Stuart Broad. To his credit Broad is a great survivor. Recently there has been discussion within the England hierarchy of Broad being one of the bowlers to be rotated or rested for the greater good. One media outlet assured us he would be dropped for this tour but he is here and eager to play. However the possibility of England wanting to play three spinners in Galle, where the ball is expected to turn in Rangana Herathâ€™s last Test, enhances the chances Broad really will be rotated this time.

Rootâ€™s response to the Broad question was Delphic; it could be interpreted in various ways. â€œI wouldnâ€™t say itâ€™s a changing of the guard and I wouldnâ€™t say heâ€™s in a weaker position than he has been previously,â€ he said.

â€œWe still havenâ€™t finalised the team. He could still definitely play a massive part within the three-match series and definitely the first game is an option. But we have struggled away from home a number of times now, so we are trying to find a different formula with him or without him.

â€œI donâ€™t think it weakens him as a player or where his game is going. I think heâ€™s actually improving all the time and using his experience wisely. His action is as strong as it has ever been but whether we have to find a different formula weâ€™ll just have to wait and see. We have to make a real, clear call on whatâ€™s going to be the best side on a given surface.â€

Sir Humphrey would have been proud of Rootâ€™s perambulation. A guess is that Broad is likely to be left out, which probably means he will produce a four for 10 spell over the next few days.

The other debate centres on the identity of the opening batsmen. Keaton Jennings is the only one in the squad who has opened regularly for England recently, yet there remains a good argument he should give way to Rory Burns and Joe Denly with the possibility of Moeen Ali continuing at No 3. In this instance runs over the next few days for any of the three new(ish) boys will be significant.

So Root has plenty to ponder though his concerns are pinpricks compared with the recent experiences of the former Sri Lanka captain Arjuna Ranatunga, who â€œfeared for his lifeâ€ at the weekend.

Until last Friday Ranatunga was a government minister; then one person was killed by his security detail amid unrest outside his former office as Ranatunga collected some of his personal effects. He has since been arrested. The political situation is volatile with the prime minister, Ranil Wickremesinghe, sacked by the president and replaced by a former president Mahinda Rajapaksa.

The England and Wales Cricket Board is continuing with its preparations for the series as planned but said: â€œWe are aware of the developments and are in constant contact with the British High Commission. We are exercising vigilance and avoiding all demonstrations or large political gatherings.â€

fields.headline: Hammond earmarks Â£500m budget boost for infrastructure
fields.standfirst: Chancellor eschews overhaul on how land is sold amid calls for more social homes
fields.trailText: Chancellor eschews overhaul on how land is sold amid calls for more social homes
fields.body:
Ministers are spending an extra Â£500m on infrastructure to encourage the construction of 650,000 more homes and restrictions on council housebuilding are being lifted but campaigners are disappointed after the chancellor withstood cross-party pressure to divert billions from landownersâ€™ profits to new homes.

The government will also consult on demolishing empty offices and turning the sites into homes and building homes on top of existing apartment blocks and offices as part of attempts to increase housebuilding to 300,000 units a year.

Developers welcomed it as â€œsensible and measuredâ€. The CPP estimates that a more radical policy could deliver an extra Â£9.3bn per year to pay for infrastructure for almost 100,000 new homes a year.

webTitle: Philip Hammond says universal credit is here to stay

fields.headline: Philip Hammond says universal credit is here to stay
fields.standfirst: Chancellor unveils extra investment as Labour calls for benefit to be fixed before next stage of rollout
fields.trailText: Chancellor unveils extra investment as Labour calls for benefit to be fixed before next stage of rollout
fields.body:
Universal credit is here to stay, Philip Hammond has said, as he announced extra investment in the flagship benefit aimed at making it more generous to some low-income working claimants.

By injecting Â£1.7bn into work allowances, the chancellor reversed much of the cut to universal credit made by his predecessor, George Osborne, in 2015 and suggested ministers were fully committed to the much-delayed benefits overhaul programme.

Hammondâ€™s cash-for-work allowances may be enough to head off a threatened revolt by Conservative backbenchers concerned that some low-income working families on tax credits would be Â£200 a month worse off after moving to universal credit.

Hammond also announced an extra Â£1bn over five years to provide extra protection for people on tax credits and other benefits who would be moved over to universal credit in the next few years. Details will be announced this year.

There will be â€œrun-onâ€ support from 2020, whereby unemployed claimants will continue to receive existing benefits for two weeks after submitting their universal credit application, in a move aimed at easing the long waiting time for a first payment.

Universal credit rolls together six working-age benefits into a single monthly payment, including jobseekerâ€™s allowance, working tax credits and housing benefits. Work allowances are the amount claimants can earn before benefits start to be withdrawn. Higher work allowances in theory encourage claimants to move into work, or work longer hours.

The Resolution Foundation thinktank welcomed the work allowance boost, saying the Â£1,000 threshold increase would deliver a Â£630 boost to low-income families, meaning universal credit was now more generous than the benefit system it was replacing.

Torsten Bell, the Resolution Foundation chief executive, said: â€œWhile todayâ€™s reforms certainly wonâ€™t end all the problems some recipients have faced with universal credit, they should ease the rollout in the months and years ahead.â€

However, opposition politicians and charities emphasised ministers had not addressed wider cuts to welfare or structural problems with universal credit, such as the long waiting times for payment that forced some families into debt or to rely on food banks.

Related: Food bank use will soar after universal credit rollout, warns charity

John McDonnell, Labourâ€™s shadow chancellor, said: â€œThe money promised for universal credit is less than a third of the Â£7bn of social security cuts still to come and todayâ€™s announcement on work allowances reverses just over half the cuts made in 2015.â€

Matthew Reed, the chief executive at the Childrenâ€™s Society, said: â€œWhile the government has taken some important steps in the right direction it has still not done enough to address serious problems with universal credit which are causing hardship for many families.â€

Alison Garnham, the chief executive of the Child Poverty Action Group, said: â€œThe work allowance increase is unequivocally good news for families receiving universal credit but a bigger salvage operation is still needed for the benefit.â€

Hammondâ€™s striking endorsement of universal credit comes after criticism from two previous prime ministers, Sir John Major and Gordon Brown, who said the changes could trigger poll tax-levels of public unpopularity.

Labour has called for universal credit to be halted and fixed before the next stage of its rollout, which will lead to 2 million claimants on tax credits and employment and support allowance migrate on to the new system during the next three years.

The chancellor has also been under intense pressure from Conservative backbenchers and poverty campaigners to restore the level of work allowances, seen by many as essential if universal credit is to uphold its original aims of incentivising work.

The chancellorâ€™s announcement on work allowances was welcomed by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, which called it â€œan important step forwardâ€ in tackling the rise of in-work poverty that it said would help ease the burden for low-income families.

webTitle: Indonesia plane crash: flight JT610 plunges into waters off Jakarta

fields.headline: Indonesia plane crash: flight JT610 plunges into waters off Jakarta
fields.standfirst: Communication lost with Lion Air plane carrying 189 people minutes after takeoff
fields.trailText: Communication lost with Lion Air plane carrying 189 people minutes after takeoff
fields.byline: Kate Lamb in Jakarta, Naaman Zhou and agencies
fields.body:
A passenger plane carrying 189 people crashed into the sea off Jakarta on Monday minutes after taking off on a domestic flight to an Indonesian tin-mining region.

Lion Air flight JT610, travelling from Jakarta to Pangkal Pinang on the island of Bangka, lost contact with air traffic control about 13 minutes after it took off, shortly after its pilot had asked to return to base. Flight data showed that it made a sudden, sharp dive into the sea.

Officials said human remains had been recovered from the crash site, about nine miles (15km) off the coast, and that they did not expect to find survivors.

The plane was a Boeing 737 Max 8 jet, a new model that was launched globally only last year. The specific plane had been in use for less than three months.

Lion Airâ€™s chief executive, Edward Sirait, told reporters the plane had suffered â€œa technical issueâ€ on Sunday night but engineers had cleared it to fly on Monday morning. â€œThis plane previously flew from Denpasar to Jakarta,â€ he said. â€œThere was a report of a technical issue, which had been resolved according to procedure.â€

Sirait did not elaborate on the specific issue, and said he had no plans to ground the rest of Lion Airâ€™s Max 8 fleet. The airline operates 11 of the Boeing planes.

Related: Lion Air crash: officials say 188 onboard lost flight JT610 â€“ latest updates

On Monday rescuers released footage of debris and personal items floating in the water at the crash site, including handbags, clothing, mobile phones, ID cards and driving licences. Dozens of divers from the national search and rescue agency and the military were working to retrieve the bodies of victims.

At Soekarno-Hatta airport in Jakarta, relatives arrived at the airport crisis centre, many too distressed to talk to the media.

Tugi, a Jakarta resident, came to inquire about his friend Wendy. â€œI came to try and get some information, but they canâ€™t give us any answers,â€ he said. â€œThey donâ€™t know yet, so I am going home and will monitor the media reports from there.â€

Forensics officers have told family members of those on board that they can assist with the identification process by providing medical and dental records at the police hospital in East Jakarta.

About 20 of the 189 people on board were Indonesian finance department officials who had travelled to Jakarta for a conference. Three children, two of them infants, and eight crewmembers were also among those on board.

A statement from Indonesiaâ€™s search and rescue agency said the aircraftâ€™s emergency locator transmitter had not sent out a distress signal despite being certified to work until August 2019.

The plane went down in waters about 30-35 metres (98-115ft) deep. Indonesiaâ€™s disaster agency spokesman posted video of debris on Twitter.

Another official said he could not confirm the cause of the crash, as the planeâ€™s black box, comprising the cockpit voice recorder and flight data recorder, had yet to be recovered. But it was confirmed that the pilot had requested to turn back shortly after takeoff.

â€œWe will collect all data from the control tower,â€ said Soerjanto Tjahjono, the official. â€œThe plane is so modern, it transmits data from the plane and that we will review too. But the most important is the black box.â€

On Monday afternoon the national search and rescue agency said it had determined the location of the black box, but had not yet managed to retrieve it.

The incident is the first to be reported that involves the widely sold Max 8, an updated, more fuel-efficient version of the common 737. The first Boeing 737 Max jets were introduced into service in 2017.

Boeing and the US National Transportation Safety Board both said on Monday that they were providing assistance to Indonesian accident investigators.

The Indonesian president, Joko Widodo, expressed his condolences in a televised address.

Australian government officials have been instructed not to fly with Lion Air until the cause of the crash can be determined.

Indonesia is one of the worldâ€™s fastest-growing aviation markets, although its safety record is patchy. The crash could potentially be the countryâ€™s second worst air disaster since 1997, industry experts said.

Reuters contributed to this report

webTitle: Hammond's budget spending highlights May's weakness | Larry Elliott

fields.headline: Hammond's budget giveaways highlight May's weakness
fields.standfirst: Short-term spending aims to placate a public the PM thinks is sick of austerity
fields.trailText: Short-term spending aims to placate a public the PM thinks is sick of austerity
fields.body:
Watching Philip Hammond deliver his third budget, it was hard to avoid thinking that an election must be in the offing. Chancellors normally show their mean streak when parliaments are young and squirrel away any available cash so that they can give money away as polling day approaches.

Not this time, though. The chancellor was in the position of knowing that public borrowing this year is on course to be Â£12bn lower than was predicted in the spring â€“ an extremely happy outcome given the economyâ€™s mediocre performance.

Less than 18 months into the current parliament, Hammond could have saved his windfall and met his stated aim of balancing the budget by the middle of the next decade. Instead he decided to blow the lot â€“ in higher spending and an unexpected income tax cut.

Related: Hammond says end of austerity is in sight as he boosts spending

The independent Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) says the UK will still be in the red by 2023-24, although in reality a great deal depends on the sort of Brexit deal the government secures. Hammond expressed cheerful optimism about the double deal bonus he would get in the event that negotiations end successfully: the end of the uncertainty that has led firms to mothball investment plans will lead to stronger growth, and there will be no need to keep money aside for a no-deal outcome.

Even so, the chancellor had to accept that he might be back with another package of measures in the spring if talks between London and Brussels break down over the coming months. In those circumstances, there will be pressure for a significant loosening of fiscal policy and all talk of balancing the budget by the middle of the next decade will go out of the window.

The budget was unashamedly political both in its tone and its content. Hammond used every opportunity to take a swing at Jeremy Corbyn and John McDonnell on the Labour benches and took delight in announcing that there would be no more PFI projects on his watch.

There could be only three possible explanations for Hammondâ€™s approach. One is that he has overnight morphed into a born-again Keynesian and has decided that a bit more growth is the way to lick the public finances back into shape. That seems unlikely.

Related: Key points from budget 2018 â€“ at a glance

A second is that the government secretly believes it is heading for a no-deal Brexit, so is giving the economy some padding before expected disruption during 2019. But if that were the case, Hammond would be keeping every bit of ammunition in reserve, not spending it now, so that does not seem all that probable either.

That leaves the third and final explanation, which is that the real architect of this budget was Theresa May â€“ not Hammond. As the chancellor rather ruefully said, it was the prime minister who announced an extra Â£84bn over five years for the NHS back in the summer, thus depriving him of a rabbit to pull out of the hat.

Whatâ€™s more, May then went further in her party conference speech and said that the public needed to know that the age of austerity was over. Those interventions left Hammond with very little wriggle room but in truth are a sign of the governmentâ€™s weakness. While Hammond boasted of the lowest unemployment since the 1970s, there was no mention of the worrying trends of recent years: flat-lining productivity, persistently weak investment, wages lower than they were a decade ago once inflation is taken into account.

May has come to the conclusion that the public is sick of austerity, so Hammondâ€™s unenviable task was to make it look as though everything bad that has happened over the past eight years was Labourâ€™s fault.

The chancellor made the best of a bad job and even managed a bit of push back to show that the Treasury was still committed to fiscal rectitude. Extra money for universal credit, repairing potholes and for schools canâ€™t disguise the fact that austerity hasnâ€™t come to an end. The Resolution Foundation thinktank calculates that the budgets of non-protected departments will be 3% lower in per capita terms in 2023 than in 2019. The freeze in working-age benefits for next year is still going ahead, saving Â£1.5bn.

The OBRâ€™s bottom line is that the budget means an extra Â£1.1bn this year, Â£10.9bn next year and Â£23.2bn by 2023-24. No chancellor â€“ not even George Osborne â€“ in the run-up to the 2015 election â€“ has been so generous since the fiscal watchdog was set up in 2010.

Hammondâ€™s attempts to show that his generosity was grounded in fiscal discipline cuts little ice with the OBR. It noted sniffily that the budget had the â€œfamiliar Augustinian pattern of a near-term giveaway followed by a longer-term takewayâ€. St Augustine, it might be remembered, was famous for saying: â€œLord make me chaste, but not yet.â€

fields.headline: Britainâ€™s last budget in the EU is a sticking plaster for a nation in decline

Here was a pothole budget, a light spray of makeshift asphalt over the riskiest craters in the public sector. The end of austerity? No, just minor repairs to a little of the damage they have done; things sounding good but signifying little.

This was a traditional Tory budget, with benefits still frozen for the poorest while three-quarters of the winnings from raising personal tax allowances flow to the top half of earners. As John Major warned, universal credit would have collapsed, and taken the government with it, without a bung. Enough? Its structural defects may sink it yet. Welcome gestures, like taxing the Amazons and Googles, turn out to be a slap on the wrist. A one-off Â£10,000 gift per primary school is almost insulting, as was the small sop for social care, while police and local councils are left high and dry.

This chancellor never disappoints because our expectations are so low, but he seems to relish universal disdain, like the Jolly Miller in the song: â€œI care for nobody, no, not I and nobody cares for me.â€. In reality he had just two key messages. Most important is the threat directed at the Brextremists behind him: if you vote down the prime ministerâ€™s deal and cause a no-deal crash out, I will be forced to deliver a punishment budget like no other. When Jacob Rees-Mogg and his cabal rage at Philip Hammondâ€™s Treasury as â€œthe bastion of remoanerismâ€; when they demand Brexit bonanzas, Hammond insists that even a good deal with the EU still only â€œminimises any negative effectâ€. Anti-Brexiters will praise him for admitting as much â€“ no possible deal can ever match the status quo of our EU membership: outside Europe lies only national decline, abrupt or gradual, depending on how we leave.

His other message was coded. Austerity is only â€œcoming to an endâ€, whatever the fantasy Theresa May danced her way into at the Conservative party conference, austerity is not over. Howls greeted his absurd claim that it was never â€œdriven by ideologyâ€: the intent was always downward, to a low-tax, small state, austere to the tips of Hammondâ€™s bony fingers.

The Resolution Foundation says the most minimalist interpretation of â€œending austerityâ€ would take Â£31bn just to stop cutting more, without restoring anything. I doubt that definition will cut the mustard with a public that sees the effect of cuts everywhere. All those â€œstrivers, grafters and carersâ€ Hammond praised in his speech can see it all around them â€“ in closed libraries, Sure Starts and day centres, in operations delayed, GP appointments as rare as gold dust, everywhere creeping public squalor.

Even in the most affluent places, the well-off step over rough sleepers outside Waitrose stores that offer collecting bins for local food banks. Job creation is indeed a British success story, but this is still the worst decade of wage stagnation since the Napoleonic era, with pay still below pre-crash levels. Growth in lower-skilled jobs â€“ warehousing, online retail pickers, catering and logistics â€“ hardly suggests his promised bright future of a â€œhigh-wage, high-skill economyâ€.

Good things were listed. Mental health still gets only half that â€œparity of esteemâ€ eternally promised, but it will help children in crisis left waiting for treatment for up to 18 months. That money is skimmed off the Â£20bn promised for the NHS, which must stagger through another stark winter.

But overall, this was a budget to bodge things with sticking plaster, put fires out with a watering can, and making do while failing to mend. None of it is likely to stop our relative descent in one measure after another â€“ GDP growth, education, health outcomes â€“ as the UK slides embarrassingly in most international rankings. This is what decline feels like.

Any chancellor would be wary of the unknowable blowback from Brexit. This was never going to be a budget to stand back and look at the broad sweep of how, why and who we tax, and what we spend it on. In the long and disreputable history of budgets, there never is a right time for radical reform, never the moment to fix the excrescences of a perverse, distorted, unjust system. Paul Johnson, the director of that great budget arbiter the Institute for Fiscal Studies, was blunt when talking to me on the eve of the budget: â€œHow is it that most of Europe raises so much more tax than we do?â€ he asked, rhetorically. He has always bemoaned Britainâ€™s demand for Swedish services delivered on American low tax rates â€“ and the abject failure of all parties to confront the voters honestly.

Take this glaring example: not one chancellor or economist defends the disgraceful failure in England since 1991 to reform council tax, as the richest pay a tiny fraction of their propertyâ€™s worth compared with the poorest. Let that stand for myriad deformities that survive only because no party has the political guts to engage in an honest conversation with voters.

Related: Budget 2018: Jeremy Corbyn lambasts 'broken promise budget' â€“ Politics live

This failure to confront voters with the need to raise more tax is not just a Tory disease, we have been left with some appalling decisions made in the Labour years. Nigel Lawsonâ€™s one good act was to equalise taxation of earned and unearned income. Gordon Brown wrecked it by reducing capital gains tax, in some cases to 10%, incentivising people to disguise income as capital gain.That turbo-charged private equity, where owners took â€œprofitsâ€ not salary and paid low tax. Labourâ€™s entrepreneurs relief has been exposed as a mighty tax dodge worth Â£2.7bn. Why did Labour cut income tax rates by 2%, a fair tax, that is politically so hard to increase? No wealth tax came in under Labour either â€“ but it should adopt the three key reforms the IFS recommends that would amount to one: level capital gains rates with income tax, revalue council tax and remove inheritance tax loopholes. A tax on lifetime gifts could abolish the much-hated inheritance tax and raise more.

The tax plans in last yearâ€™s Labour manifesto were miserably unradical. Raising the general income tax rate by 1p yields Â£5.5bn, twice as much as Labourâ€™s extra on earners over Â£80,000. Good to tax the best-off more â€“ but restoring that 2p Brown cutjust to make a budget-day splash would bring in Â£11bn. Labour should be encouraged that Johnson tells me thereâ€™s no reason why Britain should not borrow â€œa lot more, in the short to medium termâ€.

The iron borrowing corset adhered to by Hammond hampers our wretched rate of growth. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development says raising public investment by 0.5% of GDP would see GDP grow by 3.5%. Irrational fear of sustainable debt is useful to frighten voters into submission. Todayâ€™s Ispos Mori poll is the latest to show that two-thirds of voters would pay more tax for better services, so this should be the time to speak truth to the people: they will only ever get what they pay for, and that means most people, as well as the rich.

Meanwhile, lest we forget, while we count pennies and dispute winners and losers, the overheating planet is reaching a fatal tipping point, but nothing in this budget â€“ certainly not the ninth year of a fuel duty freeze â€“ can save our children and grandchildren.

fields.headline: Belfast gets Â£350m funding boost in budget
fields.standfirst: Philip Hammond also pledges Â£320m to Northern Ireland executive
fields.trailText: Philip Hammond also pledges Â£320m to Northern Ireland executive
fields.body:
Belfast landed a big budget boost, with Â£350m pledged as part of regional city deals announced by the chancellor.

Related: Philip Hammondâ€™s pre-Brexit budget â€“ whatâ€™s the verdict? | Gaby Hinsliff and others

Philip Hammond also pledged Â£320m to the Northern Ireland executive along with Â£2m cash to help Belfast city centre recover from the fire that engulfed the historic Primark building recently.

While the Â£350m is lower than the Â£450m Belfast had requested, it could be enough to secure other funding, said Esmond Birnie, a senior economist at Ulster University Business School.

â€œAlthough the amount is lower [than expected], this could be enough to secure backing elsewhere,â€ he said.

Related: Key points from budget 2018 â€“ at a glance

City regional deals are designed to help economies around the UK and have been embraced by the Scottish government, which got a Â£150m lift from the chancellor for its Tay city regional deal, which covers the council areas of Angus, Dundee, Fife and Perth & Kinross.

AodhÃ¡n Connolly, the director of the Northern Ireland Retail Consortium, said while Belfast did not get what it wanted, it represented a greater per capita spend for the local population than in other city deals.

The Belfast money, which will be spread over 10 years, will focus on the creation of centres of innovation, digital connectivity, tourism and transport. The Northern Irish city and wider economy has received a significant boost from the opening of the Titanic Belfast centre in 2012.

Hammond also announced he would be increasing funding to the transforming cities fund, with an additional Â£9m to trial new models of transport and Â£15m for digital investment in the north-east, Northern Ireland, and the south-east.

Manchester got Â£10m for a new pilot scheme to support the self-employed, while there was Â£37m extra given to the Northern Powerhouse rail project.

webTitle: Car industry shares rally after reports of China vehicle tax cut

fields.headline: Car industry shares rally after reports of China vehicle tax cut
fields.standfirst: Financial stocks also boosted by HSBC results as FTSE 100 enjoys best day for weeks
fields.trailText: Financial stocks also boosted by HSBC results as FTSE 100 enjoys best day for weeks
fields.body:
Shares in carmakers were boosted on Monday by a report that China is considering cutting vehicle sales tax to boost demand, helping European stock markets rebound after last weekâ€™s mauling.

Financial stocks also contributed to the rally, thanks to strong results from Europeâ€™s biggest bank, HSBC, as well as the decision by Standard & Poorâ€™s not to downgrade the Italian governmentâ€™s credit rating.

The STOXX 600 index, which tracks the share prices of companies across 17 European countries, ended the day 0.9% higher. Despite the bounce, the STOXX 600 remained on track for its worst monthly performance since August 2015, following the stock market turbulence through most of October.

Londonâ€™s FTSE 100 closed up 1.4%, led by HSBC, which closed up 4.8%. The FTSE 100 posted its best daily performance in five weeks, recovering some of the ground lost last week after a heavy sell-off hurt shares around the world.

The gains in Europe followed a sluggish performance in Asia, where worries about Chinaâ€™s slowing economy weighed. Wall Street started in positive territory before slipping back.

â€œEuropean markets enjoyed a stronger start to the week, despite a sell-off in China as investors digested the impact of a trade war with the US on industrial earnings,â€ said Russ Mould, investment director at AJ Bell.

Car manufacturers were the strongest performing business sector across European stock markets, up 3%. They rose sharply after a Bloomberg report said that China was considering halving its car purchase tax to 5% to support its struggling auto industry, which has been hit hard by the ongoing China-US trade war.

Investors seized on a potential good news story for a sector buffeted in recent months by falling sales, particularly of diesel models in the wake of the Volkswagen emissions scandal, and concerns about the impact of a trade war and the impending switch from combustion to electric engines.

The Chinese tax cut report lifted shares in VW, up 4% and the biggest riser among the European car makers. Daimler, BMW, Fiat, Renault and Peugeot Vauxhallâ€™s parent PSA also enjoyed a share price boost, along with car parts suppliers including Michelin, Pirelli and Continental.

Shares of General Motors, the No1 US automaker by sales, were up about 2% by mid afternoon in New York, while those of rival Ford were up by 4%. Shares of the two companies have fallen more than 20% this year.

The gains by carmakers helped offset worries over the political outlook in Germany, Europeâ€™s largest economy after the German chancellor, Angela Merkel, said she would not seek re-election as party chairwoman at a conference in early December and that her current term as chancellor would be her last.

However, analysts warned that the positive mood among European investors was unlikely to last. â€œEquity markets bounced back today as traders swopped in to snap up relatively cheap stocks. The German market has rallied thanks to a jump in car manufactures,â€ said David Madden, a market analyst at CMC Markets UK.

â€œChina is keen to keep the economy motoring along and Beijing is considering cutting the tax levied on car purchases by half â€¦ Chinaâ€™s economy is cooling, and the policy would be aimed at boosting demand.

â€œThe bullish mood has spread across Europe, but seeing as the geopolitical and economic risks still persist, the upward move might not last long.â€

The European banking sector rose 1.9% to a one-week high. Italian banks shone after the rating agency S&Pâ€™s kept its credit rating two notches above non-investment grade for Italian sovereign bonds, even though it lowered its outlook to negative, saying that the new governmentâ€™s policy plans were weighing on the countryâ€™s growth and debt prospects.

Banco BPM shares rose 5%, UBI Banca 4% and UniCredit 4.3%.
